content:
Nelson Bighetti is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.

summary: Nelson Bighetti is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.
title: Jacques Everwyn

summary: Social media have to be seen as an adversarial space because of the presence of adversaries, manipulation and disinformation. On classic sources of information, these challenges are usually handled by qualifying content (truth likelihood), and emitters (actor credibility). To adapt this approach to social media, we use influence models, behaviour analysis and community detection for emitters characterisation. This can be combined with the exploitation of knowledge bases for automatic fact checking. This paper proposes a review of this multi-domain challenge.
title: Manipulation and fake news detection on social media: a two domain survey, combining social network analysis and knowledge bases exploitation

summary: In this article, we review link prediction techniques for situation awareness in a maritime context, and draw conclusions on how the addition of attributes in a dynamic graph model could improve results on this task.
title: Achieving maritime situational awareness using knowledge graphs: a study

summary: In this article, we review link prediction techniques for situation awareness in a maritime context, and draw conclusions on how the addition of attributes in a dynamic graph model could improve results on this task.
title: Link Prediction on Dynamic Attributed Knowledge Graphs for Maritime Situational Awareness
